Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A circuit consists of a battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, a closed switch, and four resistors connected as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The resistors, labeled <math alttext="R sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> through <math alttext="R sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> in the figure, are all identical and have the same resistance <math alttext="R sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Six locations in the circuit are indicated by the labels <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>a</mtext></math> through <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></math>.

(a) In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw dots to represent the electric potential at each labeled location except location <math alttext="e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></math>. The potential is already indicated at location <math alttext="e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></math> by a dot drawn at a potential of zero.

(b) Derive an expression for the total rate at which energy is dissipated by the resistors in the circuit. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is replaced with a capacitor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. With the switch closed, the circuit is allowed to reach steady state. The switch is then opened at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, sketch a graph as follows. Note that the horizontal axis range includes an interval of time before <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.

i. Draw a line or curve to represent the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub uppercase C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> across the capacitor as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

ii. On the vertical axis, write an expression for the potential difference across the capacitor immediately before <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Express the potential difference value in terms of <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math> and physical constants, as appropriate.

In the circuit with the capacitor from part (c), Resistor <math alttext="R sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is replaced with a different resistor that has a greater resistance <math alttext="R sub new is greater than R sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>new</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. As in part (c), the circuit is allowed to reach steady state with the switch closed. The switch is then opened at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
(d) For a graph of the capacitor’s potential difference as a function of time, describe how some feature of the graph would be different than the graph you drew in part (c). Justify your answer.
Note: You only need to describe and justify one feature that would change.
